abstract.p: The β-recension of the Tārika Walda ʾAmid is the second translation of this work from Arabic into Gǝʿǝz. According to a list of Alexandrinian patriarchs at the end of the work, which was most probably extended by the translator(s) or early copyists up to Gabriel VII, the 95th patriarch of Alexandria, who held office during the reign of , i.e. in the period of their parallel offices in 1525-1540. It contains both the pre-Islamic and the Islamic parts, as well as the aforementioned list of patriarchs and an account on the ecumenical councils, which were added to Ibn al-ʿAmīd's original work after his death. According to 140-141, both Ethiopian recensions have been translated from the 'old recension' of the Arabic version of the Tārīḫ Ibn al-ʿAmīd, that is represented by the manuscript ANT from the Antonius Monastery in Egypt.

div.label: Attribution to the author by the translator.
div.note: The following text is taken from and .
div.q: በስመ፡ እግዚአብሔር፡ መሓሪ፡ ወመስተሣህል፡ ቦቱ፡ እትረዳእ፡ ወእዌጥን፡ ጽሕፈተ፡ ታሪክ፡ ዘውእቱ፡ ዜናሆሙ፡ ለአበው፡ ቀደምት፡ ወሐሳበ፡ ኍልቈ፡ መዋዕሊሆሙ፡ ለነገሥት፡ እምአዳም፡ እስከ፡ ተፍጻሜቶሙ፡ ለእስራኤል፡ ወለአሕዛብ፡ ዘአስተጋብኦ፡ ክቡር፡ ወትሩፍ፡ ክርስቶሳዊ፡ ጊዮርጊስ፡ ወልደ፡ አሚድ፡ ዘብሔረ፡ ግብጽ። ወሰላመ፡ እግዚአብሔር፡ የሀሉ፡ ላዕለ፡ ገብረ፡ እግዚአብሔር፡ንጉሥነ፡ ክሳደ፡ ጊዮርጊስ፡ ለዓለመ፡ ዓለም፡ አሜን።

div.label: Introduction
div.note: General introduction by the author containing a note on the final redaction of the work as well as chronographic and cosmographic considerations as witnessed in the Arabic edition in 176-191.

div.label: Authors Preface
div.note: Note by the author, in which he presents an outline of the work and claims that his work was already being circulated in Egypt when he decided to add a story from another source about the Persian Empire, which he calls ነገረ፡ መንክር፡ እምዜናሆሙ፡ ለነገሥት፡ ዝንጉዓን፡ ዘውእቶሙ፡ አዘም። (e.g. 'Ruzbihans history'). The following edition is taken from and .
div.q:
ስብሐት፡ ለእግዚአብሔር፡ ቀዳማዊ፡ ዘእንበለ፡ ጥንት፡ ወደኃራዊ፡ ዘእንበለ፡ ተፍጻሜት። አብ፡ ወወልድ፡ ወመንፈስ፡ ቅዱስ፡ አሐዱ፡ አምላክ፡ በመለኮቱ፡ ዘኢያገምሮ፡ መካን፡ ወኢይትአመር። ዘከመ፡ እፎ፡ ውእቱ፡ ወኢይበጽሖ፡ ሕሊና፡ ሰብእ። ወኢይረክቦ፡ አልባበ፡ እጓለ፡ እመሕያው። አምላከ፡ አማላክት፡ ወእግዚአ፡ div.label: Discourse on the temporality of the world
div.note: The following incipit and explicit are taken from .
div.q: ነገር፡ በእንተ፡ ከዊነ፡ ዓለም፡ ተጋአዙ፡ በእንተ፡ ፍጥረተ፡ ጥንተ፡ ዓለም፡ ወጠቢባንሰ፡ ቦእምኔሆሙ፡ ዘይቤ፡ እስመ፡ ብሉይ፡ ውእቱ፡ ከመ፡ ፈጣሪሁ፡ አልቦቱ፡ ጥንት፡ ወኢተፍጻሜት፡ ወረድኤትነሰ፡ እምኀበ፡ እግዚአብሔር።

div.label: Discourse on the nature of time
div.note: The following incipit and explicit are taken from .
div.q: ነገር፡ በእንተ፡ ጥያቄ፡ አዝማን፡ ወመዓልት፡ ለ፲ወ፪ክፍል፡ እንተ፡ ይእቲ፡ ሰዓታት።

div.label: Discourse about the quantity of time and how much of it has elapsed
div.note: The following incipit and explicit are taken from .
div.q: ነገር፡ በእንተ፡ መጠነ፡ አዝማን፡ ለእመ፡ ሠምረ፡ እግዚአብሔር።

div.label: Discourse on the commencement of the Creation
div.note: The following incipit and explicit are taken from .
div.q: ነገር፡ በእንተ፡ ጥንተ፡ ፍጥረት፡ ይቤ፡ መጽሐፍ፡ ወአዕረፈ፡ እግዚአብሔር፡ እምኵሉ፡ ግብሩ፡ በዕለት፡ ሰብዕ፡ ወዐረካ፡ ወቀደሳ።

div.label: The pre-Islamic history from to .
div.note: If not indicated otherwise, the following incipits or explicits of the textparts are taken from .

div.label: 1st Generation - Adam
div.q: ወይቤ፡ ለእግዚአብሔር፡ አምላክ፡ ገነት፡ ውስተ፡ ኤዴን፡ኤዶም፡ ዘመንገለ፡ ጽባሕ፡

div.label: Geographical Treatise
div.note: Based on the edition of 104-207.

div.label: Descendants of Shem
div.ab: ወኍልቆሙ፡ ለእለ፡ ተጋብኡ፡ ለሕንጻ፡ ማኅፈድ፡ ፸ወ፪መሳፍንት። እምኔሆሙ፡ እምደቂቀ፡ ሴም፡ ፳ወ፭ብእሲ። ወእሉ፡ ኀደሩ፡ እምአፍራጦስ፡ እስከ፡ ሶርያ፡ ወእስከ፡ ጽንፈ፡ ምሥራቅ። ወእምኔሆሙ፡ ሶርያውያን፡ ወአዕፃዳተ፡ ረቢዓ፡ ወደሴት፡ ወሐራምቃ፡ ወከለዳውያን፡ ወእሙንቱ፡ ሰብአ፡ ባቢሎን፡ ወፋርስ፡ወኵራሳን፡ ወፈርግያ፡ ወስንድ፡ ወህንደኬ፡ ወቴማን፡ ወጣይፍ፡ ወተማማ፡ ወ፪አብሕርት፡ ወዘመደ፡ ዓረብ። ወእለ፡ የአምሩ፡ ጽሒፈ፡ ሆህያት፡ ፰ዕብራዊ፡ ወሶርያዊ፡ ወፋርሳዊ፡ ወህንደኬ፡ ወከለዳዊ፡ ወሲኒ፡ ወሐማዚ፡ ወዐረቢ። ወሎሙ፡ እምአብሕርት፡ ኤፍራጦስ፡ ወፈለገ፡ በለክ።

div.label: Descendants of Ham
div.ab: ወእምደቂቀ፡ ካም፡ ፴ወ፪ዕደው። ወእሙንቱ፡ ኀደሩ፡ ምድረ፡ ሶርያ፡ ወምድረ፡ ከነአን፡ ወእስከ፡ ምድረ፡ ግብጽ፡ ወእስከ፡ አጽናፈ፡ ምዕራብ። እምኔሆሙ፡ ከነናውያን፡ ወፍልስጥኤማውያን፡ ወግብጽ፡ ወማሪስ፡ ወዘመደ፡ ኢትዮጵያውያን፡ ወሀገረ፡ ጸሊማን፡ ወዝንዝ፡ ወሰብአ፡ ምዕራብ፡ ወበርበር። ወሎሙ፡ እምደሰያት፡ ፳ወ፮ደሴት፡ ወአስማቲሆሙ፡ ሰርድያ፡ ወመላጥያ፡ ወቅረጦስ፡ ወዘየዓውዳ። ወሎሙ፡ ጸሐፉ፡ እምሆህያት፡ ፯ቅብጢ፡ ወኖቢ፡ ወኢትዮጵያዊ፡ ወፈርንጊ፡ ወቆላቂ፡ ወቂልቂ። ወሎሙ፡ እምአብሕርት፡ ተከዚ፡ ወእምአፍላጋት፡ ዮርዳኖስ።

div.label: Descendants of Japhet
div.ab: ወእምደቂቀ፡ ያፌት፡ ፲ወ፭ዕደው፡ ኀደሩ፡ እምነ፡ ጤግሮስ፡ እስከ፡ ጽንፈ፡ ሰሜነ፡ ዓለም። ወእምኔሆሙ፡ ትርኲ፡ ወንሕያን፡ ወጠዓርዒር፡ ወነትብ፡ ወጕጕ፡ ወማጎግ፡ ወሐርዘ፡ ዋለን፡ ወአይጋር፡ ወጸባይር፡ ወአርማንያ፡ ዘትልህቅ፡ ወአርማንያ፡ ዘትንእስ፡ ወአንጾኪያ፡ ወከልድያ፡ ወቀጰዶቅያ፡ ወከረስታ፡ ወዮናን፡ ወሮም፡ ወበረንጥያ፡ ወረውስ፡ ወደይለም፡ ወጸቃልባ፡ ወአፍረጋ፡ ወአንድሎስ፡ ወዘይተሉ፡ ለውእቱ። ወሎሙ፡ እምደሰያት፡ ፲ወ፪ደሰያት፡ እምኔሆሙ፡ ሮድስ፡ ወስቅልያ፡ ወቆጵሮስ፡ ወአቴናስ። ወእምኔሆሙ፡ ዘየአምር፡ ጽሒፈ፡ ፊደላት፡ ፯ዮናናዊ፡ ወሮማዊ፡ ወአርማንያዊ፡ ወእንድልሳዊ፡ ወአፍርንጋዊ፡ ወሕርዛዊ። ወሎሙ፡ እምአብሕርት፡ ጤግሮስ፡ ወሲጥ። ይቤ፡ ጸሓፌ፡ ዝንቱ፡ መጽሐፍ፡ እስመ፡ ተዘከርኩ፡ ክፍላተ፡ ኵሉ፡ ምድር፡ ዘከመ፡ ተካፈልዋ፡ ደቂቀ፡ ኖኅ።

div.label: Margins of inhabited earth
div.ab: ወካዕበ፡ ይደልወነ፡ ከመ፡ ንክሥት፡ ዝየ፡ወሰኖሙ፡ ለበሓውርት፡ ወአምሳላቲሃ፡ ወዘሀሎ፡ ውስቴታ፡ እምተአምራት፡ ወመንክራት። ወንዘክር፡ ዘጠየቅናሁ፡ እምግባራተ፡ ሕዝብ፡ ወአሕዛብ፡ እለ፡ የኀድርዋ፡ ወግብራት፡ እለ፡ ሀለዉ፡ ዲቤሃ፡ እምቀዳሚ፡ ትውልድ። ወንዜኑ፡ ዘውስተ፡ በሓውርት፡ እምአናብስት፡ ወእንስሳት፡ ወአዕዋፍ፡ ወአራዊት፡ ዘውስተ፡ ኵሉ፡ ብሔር። ወክፍላቶሙሰ፡ ለአህጉር፡ በከመ፡ ዘከረ፡ በጥሊሞስ፡ ጠቢብ። ይትከፈሉ፡ ኀበ፡ ፭ክፍል፡ ወ፬እምኔሆሙ፡ በድው፡ ወኢየኀድሩ፡ ውስቴቶሙ፡ ሰብእ፡ ወኢመኑሂ። ክፍል፡ ቀዳማይ፡ ውእቱ፡ ወሰነ፡ ምሥራቅ፡ ውስቴቱ፡ እሳተ፡ ዋዕይ፡ ወትረ። ኢየሐይዉ፡ እንስሳ። ወክፍል፡ ዳግማይ፡ ጸጋማዊ፡ ዘመንገለ፡ የማነ፡ መስዕ፡ ክፍል፡ ቀዳማይ። ይፈደፍድ፡ ዋዕዩ፡ ጥቀ፡ እስመ፡ ቅሩብ፡ እምኔሁ። ወኢይክል፡ ይኅድር፡ ውስቴቱ፡ ወኢመኑሂ። ወክፍል፡ ሣልሳዊ፡ መንገለ፡ ምዕራብ። ወውስቴቱ፡ አብሕርት፡ ዘኢይትከሀል፡ ሐዊር፡ ውስቴቶሙ፡ ወደሰያቲሁ፡ በድው። ወክፍል፡ ራብዕሰ፡ ጸጋማዊ፡ ዘየማን፡ መንገለ፡ ብሔር፡ ሳብዕ። ውስቴቱ፡ ብዙኅ፡ ቍር፡ ፈድፋደ፡ ወዕፁብ፡ ይብሰቱ። ወይወርድ፡ ውስቴቱ፡ በረድ፡ ወአስሐትያ፡ ወትረ። ወኢየኀድሩ፡ ውስቴቱ፡ አራዊት፡ ወእንስሳ። ወክፍል፡ ኃምስ፡ ውእቱ፡ ዝንቱ፡ ዘየኀድሩ፡ ውስቴቱ፡ ሰብእ፡ ማእከለ፡ ምድር። ወዝንቱ፡ ይትከፈል፡ ፯ክፍለ። ወእሙንቱ፡ በሓውርት፡ ፯፡ ዘዝኩራን፡ ወስሙዓን፡ እለ፡ ይትኌለቁ።

div.label: Earth and Sun
div.ab: ወይደሉ፡ ከመ፡ ንክሥት፡ ቅድመ፡ እስመ፡ ምድር፡ ክቡብ፡ ከመ፡ ኮራ። ወዝንቱ፡ ክፍል፡ ማእከሌሃ፡ እለ፡ የኀድሩ፡ ውስቴታ፡ ኵሉ፡ ፍጥረት፡ ይትሌዐል፡ ፈድፋደ፡ እምእሉ፡ ፬ክፍል፡ ዘበድው። ወእሉሰ፡ ፬ክፍል፡ መትሕታን፡ ጥቀ፡ እምነ፡ ኃምሳይ። ወበእንተዝ፡ ይሴወር፡ ፀሐይ፡ እምዝንቱ፡ ብሔር፡ ሶበ፡ ተሐውር፡ ውስተ፡ አጽናፈ፡ በሐውርት፡ መትሕታውያት፡ ወትበጽሕ፡ ጽልመት። ወትሰመይ፡ ውእተ፡ ጊዜ፡ ሌሊት። ወነዊኅ፡ መዓልት፡ ሶበ፡ የዓርግ፡ ፀሐይ፡ ውስተ፡ ፍኖተ፡ ጸጋም፡ እምፈለካት፡ ፲ወ፪ኀበ፡ ርእሰ፡ ኮከበ፡ ሰረጣን። ወኖኃ፡ ተፍጻሜተ፡ ሌሊት፡ ኀበ፡ ይወርድ፡ ፀሐይ፡ ውስተ፡ ፈለከ፡ ደቡባውያት፡ እንተ፡ ዘከርነ፡ ከመ፡ እሙንቱ፡ ዕፁባተ፡ ቍር።

div.label: First clime
div.ab: ወዘከረ፡ በጥሊሞስ፡ ከመ፡ ብሔር፡ ቀዳማዊ፡ እም፯በሓውርት፡ ጥንቱ፡ እምቀሪበ፡ መካነ፡ ምድረ፡ ዋዕይት። ወዝንቱ፡ ብሔር፡ ውእቱ፡ መንገለ፡ ህንደኬ፡ ወሲን፡ ዘይርኅቅ። ወዕለቱ፡ ዘትነውኅ፡ ይሰሐብ፡ ፲ወ፫ሰዓተ።

div.label: Second clime
div.ab: ወብሔር፡ ደግምሰ፡ ውእቱ፡ ሀገረ፡ ኵሳ፡ እስከ፡ ኢትዮጵያ። ወይሰሐብ፡ መዓልቱ፡ ዘይነውኅ፡ ፲ወ፫ሰዓተ፡ ወመንፈቀ፡ ሰዓት።

div.label: Third clime
div.ab: ወብሔር፡ ሣልስሰ፡ ውእቱ፡ ብሔረ፡ እስክንድርያ፡ ወግብጽ። ወይሰሐብ፡ መዓልቱ፡ ዘይነውኅ፡ ፲ወ፬ሰዓተ።

div.label: Fourth clime
div.ab: ወብሔር፡ ራብዕሰ፡ ትሰመይ፡ በሮማይስጢ፡ ሩድስ፡ ደሴት፡ እንተ፡ ውስተ፡ ባሕር። ወይትጋባእ፡ ውስተ፡ ዝንቱ፡ ብሔር፡ አህጉረ፡ ሶርያ፡ ወአህጉረ፡ ደሴት፡ ወውስቴታ፡ ባቢሎን፡ ወካልአን፡ አህጉር። ወይሰሐብ፡ መዓልቱ፡ ዘይነውኅ፡ ፲ወ፬ሰዓተ፡ ወመንፈቀ፡ ሰዓት።

div.label: Fifth clime
div.ab: ወብሔር፡ ኃምስሰ፡ ይሰመይ፡ በሮማይስጢ፡ ጰንጦስ፡ ወውስቴታ፡ ቊስጥንጥንያ፡ ወአሞርያ፡ ወሮምያ። ወይሰሐብ፡ መዓልቱ፡ ዘይነውኅ፡ ፲ወ፭ሰዓተ።

div.label: Sixth clime
div.ab: ወብሔር፡ ሳድስሰ፡ ውእቱ፡ ሀገረ፡ በርጋን፡ ወዘየዐውዳ። ወይሰሐብ፡ መዓልቱ፡ ዘይነውኅ፡ ፲ወ፭ሰዓተ፡ ወመንፈቀ፡ ሰዓት።

div.label: Seventh clime
div.ab: ወብሔር፡ ሳብዕሰ፡ ትሰመይ፡ በሮማይስጥ፡ ያሮስ፡ ወዘየዐውዳ። ወይሰሐብ፡ መዓልቱ፡ ዘይነውኅ፡ ፲ወ፮ሰዓተ።

div.label: Width of the inhabited earth
div.ab: ወንዘከር፡ ይእዜኒ፡ ኑኃ፡ ኵሉ፡ ብሔር፡ ለለ፩፡ እምነ፡ ፯በሓውርት፡ እለ፡ የኀድሩ፡ ውስቴቶሙ፡ ሰብእ። ወግድሙ፡ ንበል፡ ከመ፡ ግድሞሙ፡ ለ፯በሓውርት፡ እለ፡ የኀድሩ፡ ውስቴቶሙ፡ ሰብእ፡ እለ፡ ማእከለ፡ ምድር፡ ጥንቶሙ፡ ህንደኬ፡ ወሲን፡ ዘይርኅቅ፡ መንገለ፡ ምድር፡ እንተ፡ ታውዒ፡ እስከ፡ ተፍጻሜተ፡ ብሔረ፡ ሳብዕ፡ ዘውእቱ፡ እምጽንፈ፡ ደቡብ፡ እስከ፡ መንገለ፡ ጸጋም፡ ወግድመ፡ ዝንቱ፡ ኵሉ፡ ፷ወ፫መዓርግ፡ ዘከፈለ፡ ጠቢብ፡ በጥሊሞስ። ወግድሙ፡ ለለኵሉ፡ ብሔር፡ ፱መዓርግ። ወለለ፡ ፩መዓርግ፡ ፫ከዋክብት። ወይከውን፡ ፳ወ፯ከዋክብት። ወለለ፡ ፩መዓርግ፡ ፻ምዕራፍ።

div.label: Length of the inhabited earth
div.ab: ወጥንቱ፡ ለዝንቱ፡ ብሔር፡ እመንገለ፡ ምሥራቅ፡ እስከ፡ ተፍጻሜቱ፡ እመንገለ፡ ምዕራብ። ወይከውን፡ ኑኁ፡ ፻ወ፹መዓርግ። ወመንፈቁ፡ ለፈለካት፡ መልዕልቱ፡ ወመንፈቁ፡ መትሕቱ። ወኵሉ፡ ኑኁ፡ እመንገለ፡ ባሕረ፡ ውቅያኖስ፡ እስከ፡ ርእሱ፡ ለምዕራብ፡ ፻፷ማኅደረ፡ ከዋክብት። ፻፷ኆልቆሙ፡ ፶፻ወ፯፻ፈርሰክ፡ በከመ፡ ሐሳበ፡ ፋርስ፡ ወሰብአ፡ ምሥራቅ። ወፈርሰክሰ፡ ብሂል፡ ፬ምዕራፍ። ወንበል፡ ከመ፡ ግድሙ፡ ለዝንቱ፡ ብሔር፡ ቀዳማይ፡ ዘጥንቱ፡ እምወሰነ፡ ምድር፡ እንተ፡ ታውዒ፡ ወይበጽሕ፡ እስከ፡ ወሰነ፡ ሰረንዲብ። ወመጠነ፡ ግድሙ፡ እምደቡብ፡ እስከ፡ ጸጋም፡ ፪፻፹ወ፭ፈርሰክ።

div.label: The seven climes and their inhabitants
Inhabitants of the first clime
div.ab: ወእለ፡ የኀድሩ፡ ውስተ፡ ዝንቱ፡ ብሔር፡ ሲን፡ ዘይርኅቅ፡ ወህንዳኬ፡ እምጽንፈ፡ ምድር፡ እመንገለ፡ ምሥራቅ፡ እስከ፡ ተፍጻሜቱ፡ እመንገለ፡ ምዕራብ፡ ፩መርኅብ፡ ወእሙንቱ፡ ሰብእ፡ ዕሩቃን፡ ወትረ፡ ለዓለም፡ ሕሡም፡ ራእዮሙ፡ ወእኩይ፡ ፍጥረቶሙ፡ ወገጾሙ። ወእሙንቱ፡ ውሉደ፡ ካም። ወሎሙ፡ አእምሮ፡ በማሪት፡ ወሥራይ። ወመዋዕሊሆሙ፡ ነዊኅ። ወበውስተ፡ ውእቱ፡ ብሔር፡ አራዊት፡ ወእንስሳ፡ ዐበይት፡ ግሩማን፡ ፈድፋደ፡ ወአዕዋፍ፡ ዐበይት፡ እምኔሆሙ፡ አዕዋፍ፡ ዘምስለ፡ እንስሳ፡ ወዖፍ፡ በከመ፡ ሰገኖ፡ ወአግሪጳ፡ ወአልያጦን፡ ወዖፍ፡ ዘይሰመይ፡ ዖፈ፡ ሐርማዝ። ወበውስተ፡ ዝንቱ፡ ብሔር፡ ሐርማዛት፡ ዐበይት፡ ወአክይስት፡ ግሩማን፡ ወአርዌ፡ ዐቢይ። ወሰብኡ፡ ቦእምኔሆሙ፡ ሎሙ፡ አእምሮ፡ በዕፀው፡ ወበአእባን፡ እንተ፡ ፍጥረቶሙ፡ ወከዊኖሙ፡ መድኀኒተ። ይከውን፡ ቦቱ፡ ፈውሰ፡ እሙንቱ፡ አክይስት፡ ወአራዊት፡ ግሩማን። ይቀብዑ፡ ቦሙ፡ ለዘነሰኮ፡ እምእሙንቱ፡ አክይስት፡ እኩያት፡ ወየሐዩ።

div.label: Inhabitants of the second clime
div.ab: ብሔረ፡ ዳግማይሰ፡ ዘውእቱ፡ ኢትዮጵያ። ግድሙ፡ ይበጽሕ፡ ኀበ፡ ወሰነ፡ ሰረንዲብ፡ እስከ፡ ተፍጻሜተ፡ ሀገረ፡ ኢትዮጵያ፡ እመንገለ፡ ምዕራብ፡ ወመንገለ፡ አድባር፡ እንተ፡ ይትረከብ፡ እምኔሃ፡ ያክንት፡ ወዕንቈ፡ ባሕርይ፡ ወሙዳየ፡ ወርቅ። ወእለ፡ የኀድሩ፡ ውስቴቱ፡ ሲን፡ ዘይቀርብ፡ ወስንድ፡ ወህንደኬ። ወውስተ፡ ዛቲ፡ ብሔር፡ ካዕበ፡ እንስሳ፡ ወአራዊት፡ ዐበይት፡ ወግሩማት። ወእሙንቱሰ፡ ይንዕሱ፡ እምዘ፡ ውስተ፡ ብሔር፡ ቀዳሚ። ወበውስተ፡ ዝንቱ፡ ብሔር፡ ዕፀው፡ ወአእባን፡ ይከውን፡ ቦሙ፡ ፈውስ፡ ለዘነሰኮ፡ እምአራዊት፡ በዘውስተ፡ ፍጥረቶሙ፡ እምውእቱ። ወቦ፡ እምእለ፡ የኀድሩ፡ ውስተ፡ ዝንቱ፡ ብሔር፡ ዘሎቱ፡ አእምሮ፡ በማሪት፡ ወሥራይ፡ ወፈውሳት፡ በዕፀው፡ ወአእባን። ወመዋዕሊሆሙ፡ የሐጽጽ፡ እመዋዕለ፡ እለ፡ የኀድሩ፡ ውስተ፡ ብሔር፡ ቀዳማይ። ወኑኁሰ፡ ወግድሙ፡ በከመ፡ ብሔር፡ ቀዳማይ።

div.label: Inhabitants of the third clime
div.ab: ወብሔረ፡ ሣልስሰ፡ ውእቱ፡ ብሔረ፡ እስክንድርያ። ወዝንቱ፡ ብሔር፡ ጥንቱ፡ እምርእሰ፡ አህጉረ፡ ግብጽ፡ እመንገለ፡ ምዕራብ፡ ምሥራቁ፡ እመንገለ፡ ምድረ፡ ሰንዶስ። ወይበጽሕ፡ ግድሙ፡ እመንገለ፡ ምዕራብ፡ እስከ፡ ወሰነ፡ ሶርያ፡ እንተ፡ አፍአይት፡ ወፋርስ፡ ቀዳማይ፡ ወእስከ፡ ወሰነ፡ እስክንድርያ፡ ወአጽናፊሁ፡ ብርቃ፡ ወአፍራቂያ፡ ቀዳሚት። ወእለ፡ የኀድሩ፡ ውስተ፡ ዝንቱ፡ ብሔር፡ ሰብእ፡ ሐታትያን፡ በእንተ፡ ምግባራት፡ ህልዋት። ወኑኁ፡ ወግድሙ፡ ከመ፡ ቀዳሚ።

div.label: Inhabitants of the fourth clime
div.note: Including a list of the ten sciences.
div.ab: ወብሔረ፡ ራብዕሰ፡ ዘውስተ፡ ማእከለ፡ ደሴት፡ ሮድስ። ወአህጉሪሁኒ፡ ብዙኅ። ወንሕነ፡ ንዘከር፡ ኅዳጠ፡ ዘአእመርነ፡ እምኔሆሙ፡ በእንተ፡ ጥያቄ፡ ኍልቆሙ፡ ዘውእቶሙ፡ ደማስቆ፡ ወሕምጽ፡ ወቀይሰሪን፡ ወሐለብ፡ ወመንበግ፡ ወፋምያ፡ ወአንጾኪያ፡ ወካራን፡ ወሩሕ፡ ወርቃ፡ ወርእሰ፡ ዓይን፡ ወንጽቢን፡ ወሶርያ፡ ወባቅዳድ፡ ወዐረብያ። ወይበጽሕ፡ ወሰናቱ፡ እምርእሱ፡ ዘምሥራቅ፡ ፩ርኅብ፡ እስከ፡ መንገለ፡ ምዕራብ። ወይበጽሕ፡ እምአህጉረ፡ አስፋር፡ ወይበጽሕ፡ መንፈቀ፡ ሀገረ፡ አፍራቂያ፡ መንገለ፡ ፀጋመ፡ ሰቁልያ፡ ወሀገረ፡ አፍራጢ፡ ማዕዶታት፡ ወሀገረ፡ አንቂያስ፡ እምአህጉረ፡ ሮም፡ ምስለ፡ ቆብሮስ፡ ወእስያ፡ ዐበይት። ወዝንቱ፡ ብሔር፡ ውእቱ፡ ማእከለ፡ ምድር። ወበእንተ፡ ዝንቱ፡ ይኄይስ፡ እምኵሉ፡ አህጉር፡ በዓየሩ፡ ወነፋሱ፡ ወዕሩየ፡ ጠባይዑ። ወበእንተ፡ ዝንቱ፡ ኮኑ፡ ሰብእ፡ እለ፡ የኀድሩ፡ ውስቴቱ፡ ጠቢባን፡ ወፈላስፋ፡ ወማእምራነ፡ ከዋክብት፡ ወመምህራነ፡ ጥበብ። ወየሐትቱ፡ በእንተ፡ ምግባራት፡ ህልዋት፡ ወጠባይዐት፡ ወበእንተ፡ ባሕርያውያት። ወበኀቤሆሙ፡ አመሩ፡ መጻሕፍተ፡ ከመ፡ ተጋብኡ፡ ተአምራት፡ ወመንክራት፡ ወአእምሮታት፡ ዘ፲። ወይእቲ፡ አእምሮ፡ ፈለካት፡ ወሁከታተ፡ ከዋክብት፡ ወፍትሕ፡ ባቲ። ወአእምሮ፡ ጥበበ፡ መስፈርተ፡ ምድር። ወተኬንዎ። ወሐሳበ፡ ዘይከውን። ወአእምሮ፡ ሙሲቂ፡ ዝውእቱ፡ ሠራዕያነ፡ ዜማ። ወአእምሮ፡ ግብረ፡ ጥበብ፡ ከመ፡ ይፈውሱ፡ ኵሎ፡ እንስሳ፡ እምኵሉ፡ ሕማሞሙ፡ ይፈውሱ፡ እንስሳ፡ ነባቤ፡ ዝውእቱ፡ ሰብእ፡ ወካዕበ፡ ይፈውስዎሙ፡ ለእንስሳ፡ ዘኢይነብቡ፡ ወአዕዋፍ፡ ወካልአን። ወአእምሮ፡ ገቢረ፡ ወርቅ፡ ወብሩር፡ በጥበብ። ወአእምሮ፡ ምትሀታት፡ ወመዐልማት። ወአእምሮ፡ ፍካሬያተ፡ ነቢብ፡ እንተ፡ ትፈልጥ፡ ወትጤይቅ፡ እሙነ፡ ነገረ፡ እምካልእ። ወአእምሮ፡ ፈላስፋ፡ ወውእቱ፡ አእምሮ፡ መለኮታዊ። ወእለ፡ የኀድሩ፡ ውስተ፡ ዝንቱ፡ ብሔር፡ ይከብሩ፡ በጥበብ፡ ወፈለስፋ። ወእሙንቱ፡ ይኄይሱ፡ እምእለ፡ የኀድሩ፡ ውስተ፡ ብሔር፡ ሣልስ፡ በእንተ፡ ቅጥነተ፡ ልቦሙ፡ ወአእምሮቶሙ፡ ወበእንተ፡ ጥዑም፡ ነፋሰ፡ ሀገሮሙ። ወኑኁሰ፡ ወግድሙ፡ ውእቱ፡ በከመ፡ አቅደምነ፡ ነጊረ።

div.label: Inhabitants of the fifth clime
div.ab: ወብሔረ፡ ኃምስሰ፡ ዘዕውቅ፡ በህሉስ፡ ወብንጡስ። ወውእቱ፡ ዘውስቴቱ፡ ቍስጥንጥንያ፡ ወአሞርያ፡ ወሮምያ፡ ወአንድሎስ፡ ወአህጉረ፡ አፍራቂ። ወእለ፡ የኀድሩ፡ ውስቴቱ፡ ሰብእ፡ ቀይሓን፡ ዘፍትወቶሙ፡ ብዙኅ፡ ወጽኑዓን፡ ፈድፋደ፡ ቍጡዓን፡ ወመዓትማን፡ ወከመዝ፡ ኮነ፡ ዔሳው፡ አቡሆሙ። ወእሙንቱ፡ ውሑዳነ፡ ጥበብ፡ ወአእምሮ፡ እምብሔረ፡ ራብዕ። ወእሙንቱ፡ ሰብእ፡ ዕፁባን፡ አልቦሙ፡ ተግሣጽ፡ አላ፡ እሙንቱ፡ ያስተፋጥኑ፡ ለተወክፎ፡ ተግሣጽ፡ ወይትመሐሩ፡ ፍጡነ። አላ፡ እለ፡ የኀድሩ፡ ውስተ፡ ብሔር፡ ራብዕ፡ ቀጢናን፡ ወንጹሓነ፡ ልብ፡ እምእለ፡ የኀድሩ፡ ውስተ፡ ዝንቱ፡ ብሔር። ኑኁሰ፡ ወግድሙ፡ በከመ፡ ቀዳሚ።

div.label: Inhabitants of the sixth clime
div.note: Including a description of the Amazons.
div.ab: ወብሔረ፡ ሳድስሰ፡ ዘዕውቅ፡ በሶርዮ፡ ጦሚስ፡ እምደሰያተ፡ ባሕር። ወእለ፡ የኀድሩ፡ ውስተ፡ ዝንቱ፡ ብሔር፡ በርጋን፡ ወሰቃልባ፡ ወባዕዳን፡ አሕዛብ። ወውስቴቱ፡ አንስት፡ የኀድራ፡ መንገለ፡ ዝንቱ፡ ብሔር፡ ባሕቲቶን፡ ወኢየኀድሩ፡ ምስሌሆን፡ ብእሲ። ወውእቶን፡ ይመትራ፡ አጥባቲሆን፡ ዘየማን፡ ወትረ፡ ወይወድዩ፡ ውስቴቱ፡ እሳት፡ ከመ፡ ኢይልሀቅ፡ ወኢያውኀዝ፡ ደመ፡ እስመ፡ እማንቱ፡ ድልዋት፡ ለጸብእ፡ ወለቀቲል፡ እስመ፡ ሳምርስ፡ ይጸብእዎን፡ ወይቀትሉ፡ ውሉዶን፡ እለ፡ ወለዳ፡ ተባዕተ። ወበእንተዝ፡ ኢየሐፅና፡ ተባዕተ፡ ውሉዶን፡ አላ፡ የሐፅናሆን፡ ለአንስት፡ ባሕቲቶን። ወለለኵሉ፡ ዓመት፡ የሐውራ፡ ኀበ፡ አህጉረ፡ ዕደው፡ ወይትዋሰባ፡ ወይፀንሳ። ወእምከመ፡ ፀንሳ፡ ይትመየጣ፡ ኀበ፡ አብያቲሆን። ወዝንቱ፡ ነገር፡ ዕውቅ፡ ወኢይናፍቅ፡ ቦቱ፡ መኑሂ። ወሰብአ፡ ዝንቱ፡ ብሔር፡ እለ፡ ያፀንሱ፡ አንስተ፡ ምሁራነ፡ ቀትል፡ ዕደወ፡ ጸብእ፡ ወከዓውያነ፡ ደም። ወአልቦሙ፡ ምሕረት። ወበእንተዝ፡ ይፄውዎሙ፡ ለሰቃልባ፡ ወይገብርዎሙ፡ ኅጽዋነ። ወእሙንቱ፡ ሰብእ፡ አልቦሙ፡ አእምሮ፡ ወኢምንትኒ፡ እመጻሕፍት፡ ተግሣጻት፡ ወትምህርታት። ኑኁሰ፡ ወግድሙ፡ በከመ፡ ቀዳሚ።

div.label: Inhabitants of the seventh clime
div.ab: ወብሔረ፡ ሳብዕሰ፡ ዘዕውቅ፡ በያርስ፡ ባርስ። ወውእቱ፡ ብሔር፡ ዘየኀድሩ፡ ውስቴቱ፡ ሰብእ፡ እለ፡ ይሰመዩ፡ በሮማይስጥ፡ በሚዶስ፡ ዝብሂል፡ ደቃስያን። ወእሙንቱ፡ ሰብእ፡ ድኩማነ፡ ኀይል፡ ወውኁዳነ፡ ተሀውኮ፡ በእንተ፡ ብዝኀ፡ ቊር፡ ዕፁብ፡ ላዕሌሆሙ፡ እስመ፡ እሙንቱ፡ ቅሩባን፡ እመንገለ፡ ጸጋም፡ ወመካናተ፡ በድው፡ ዘኢየኀድሩ፡ ውስቴቶሙ፡ ሰብእ። ወከዋክብት፡ እንተ፡ ይሰመዩ፡ አዋልደ፡ አራት፡ በቅሩብ፡ እምኔሆሙ፡ የዓውዱ፡ ወትረ፡ ላዕሌሆሙ። እንስሳሆሙ፡ ወአራዊተ፡ ሀገሮሙ፡ ንዑሳን፡ ፈድፋደ። አልቦ፡ ለአልህምቲሆሙ፡ ወለአባግዒሆሙ፡ አቅርንት፡ በእንተ፡ ጽንዐ፡ ቍር፡ ዘህየ። ወኢይትረከብ፡ ውስተ፡ ሀገሮሙ፡ ምንትኒ፡ እምአክይስት፡ ወዘይትሐወስ። ወኢይክሉ፡ ይሕንጹ፡ አብያተ፡ ከመ፡ ይኅድሩ፡ ዳእሙ፡ ይገብሩ፡ አብያተ፡ እምዕፀው፡ ወያነብርዎ፡ ላዕለ፡ ሰረገላ፡ ወየኀድሩ፡ ውስቴቱ፡ ወይስህብዎ፡ አልህምቲሆሙ። ወየሐውሩ፡ ሌሊተ፡ ወመዓልተ፡ እንዘ፡ ይስሕቡ፡ አልህምቲሆሙ፡ ውእተ፡ መንኰራኵረ፡ ኀበ፡ ይረክቡ፡ ሲሳየ፡ ወምርዓየ፡ ለእንስሳሆሙ። ወእሙንቱ፡ በኵሉ፡ መዋዕሊሆሙ፡ ኅሡራን፡ በእኩይ፡ ግብር፡ ወሕይወት። ወተብህለ፡ በእንቲአሆሙ፡ እስመ፡ እሙንቱ፡ ሶበ፡ የሐሙ፡ ሕማመ፡ ዕፁበ፡ ያነብሩ፡ ድውያኒሆሙ፡ ዲበ፡ ሰረገላ። ወየአትቱ፡ አልባሰ፡ እምላዕሌሆሙ፡ አልባሰ፡ እደው፡ ወያለብስዎሙ፡ ልብሰ፡ አንስት፡ ወይትፌወሱ። ኑኁ፡ ወግድሙ፡ ከመ፡ ቀዳሚ።

div.label: Inhabitants of the regions above the seventh clime
div.note: Including a description of the polar night and polar day.
div.ab: ይቤ፡ ወዘተርፈሰ፡ እምተፍጻሜተ፡ ፷ወ፫ክፍል፡ በግድም፡ ወውእቱሰ፡ ዘተሰምየ፡ መልዕልተ፡ ብሔር፡ ሳብዕ። ወኢይሴስል፡ መዓልት፡ ሶበ፡ ይነውኅ፡ መንገለ፡ ጸጋም፡ ይከውን፡ ድኅረ፡ ምድር፡ እለ፡ ይነብሩ፡ ሰብእ፡ ውስቴታ፡ ፳ወ፩ሰዓተ፡ ፳ወ፪ቅጽበተ፡ እምሰዓት፡ እስከ፡ ይበጽሕ፡ መዓልት፡ ኀበ፡ ፳ወ፬። ወኢይሴስል፡ ብርሃነ፡ መዓልት፡ ከመዝ፡ እስከ፡ ኀበ፡ ብሔረ፡ ጽልመት። ይከውን፡ ህየ፡ ሌሊት፡ ፮አውራኀ፡ ወመዓልት፡ ፮አውራኀ። ወተአምራት፡ ዘኮነ፡ ውስተ፡ ምድር፡ በበሀገሩ፡ ወጠልሰማት፡ ዘጽህቀ፡ ወዘገብሮ፡ እስመ፡ ብዙኅ፡ ውእቱ፡ ወአልቦቱ፡ ኍልቍ፡ ለሐሳቡ። ወንሕነ፡ ንዘከር፡ ዘተጽሕፈ፡ ኅዳጠ፡ ውስተ፡ መጽሐፈ፡ ታሪክ፡ ዘአመርናሁ፡ ወኢወሰክነ፡ በጽሒፎቱ፡ ከመ፡ ኢይኑኅ፡ ነገር።

div.label: The Indian sea
div.ab: ወካዕበ፡ መጠኑ፡ ወሰፈሩ፡ ባሕረ፡ ህንደኬ። ወይቤሉ፡ ከመ፡ ውእቱ፡ ይሰሐብ፡ ኑኁ፡ እምዕራብ፡ እስከ፡ ምሥራቅ፡ ወውእቱ፡ እምጽንፈ፡ ህንደኬ፡ እስከ፡ ጽንፈ፡ ኢትዮጵያ፡ ይከውን፡ ኑኁ፡ ፹፻ምዕራፍ፡ ወግድሙ፡ ፳፻ወ፯፻ምዕራፍ፡ እስከ፡ ይለጽቅ፡ ደሴተ፡ ዘዕሩይ፡ ሌሊተ፡ ወመዓልተ። ወይከውን፡ ጽንፈ፡ ካልእ፡ ፳፻ወ፱፻። ወእምኔሁ፡ ፩ፈለግ፡ ንኡስ፡ ውስተ፡ ምድረ፡ ኢትዮጵያ፡ ይሰሐብ፡ እስከ፡ መንገለ፡ በርባር። ወይሰመይ፡ ፈለገ፡ በርባራዊ። ኑኁሰ፡ ፭፻ምዕራፍ፡ ወግድመ፡ ጽንፉ፡ ፻ምዕራፍ። ወሎቱ፡ ካልእ፡ ፈለግ፡ መንገለ፡ አይላ። ኑኁ፡ ፲፻ወ፬፻ምዕራፍ፡ ወግድሙ፡ ፯፻ምዕራፍ። ወተፍጻሜቱ፡ ዝውእቱ፡ ጽንፉ፡ ዘይቀርብ፡ ውስተ፡ ዘይሰመይ፡ ባሕረ፡ ኤርትራ፡ ፪፻ምዕራፍ። ወሎቱ፡ ካልእ፡ ፈለግ፡ ይወፅእ፡ ኀበ፡ መንገለ፡ ፋርስ፡ ይሰመይ፡ ፈለገ፡ ፋርሳዊ። ኑኁ፡ ፲፻ወ፬፻ምዕራፍ፡ ወግድሙ፡ ፭፻ምዕራፍ፡ ወጽንፉ፡ ፻፶ምዕራፍ። ወማእከለ፡ ዝንቱ፡ ፪አብሕርት፡ ምድረ፡ ቄዳር፡ ወልደ፡ እስማኤል፡ ወምድረ፡ የማን። ወይከውን፡ ዘማእከለ፡ ፈለገ፡ አይላ፡ ወፈለገ፡ ፋርስ፡ ፲፻ወ፭፻ምዕራፍ። ወይወፅእ፡ እምኔሁ፡ ፈለግ፡ ካልእ፡ እስከ፡ ጽንፈ፡ ምድረ፡ ህንደኬ፡ ኀበ፡ ተፍጻሜቱ። ወይሰመይ፡ ፈለገ፡ ሐመልሚል። ወይከውን፡ አንጻረ፡ ምድረ፡ ህንደኬ፡ እመንገለ፡ ምድረ፡ ህንደኬ፡ እምሥራቅ፡ ወይሰመይ፡ ጢራባይ። የዐውድ፡ ቦቱ፡ ፴፻ምዕራፈ። ውስቴታ፡ አድባር፡ ዐበይት፡ ወአፍላጋት፡ ብዙኅ። እምኔሃ፡ ይወፅእ፡ መረግድ፡ ቀይሕ፡ ወኅብረ፡ ሰማይ። ወየዐውዳ፡ ለዛቲ፡ ደሴት፡ ፺ደሰያት፡ የኀድሩ፡ ውስቴቶሙ፡ ሰብእ፡ ወአህጉር፡ ብዙኅ።

div.label: The Green sea
div.ab: ወባሕረ፡ ሐመልሚልሰ፡ ኢይትዐወቅ፡ እምኔሁ፡ ዘእንበለ፡ ዘይበጽሕ፡ መንገለ፡ ምዕራብ፡ ወጸጋም፡ እምጽንፈ፡ ምድረ፡ ኢትዮጵያ፡ እስከ፡ በርጦንያ። ወውእቱ፡ ባሕር፡ ኢየኀውሩ፡ ውስቴቱ፡ አሕማራት። ወ፯ደሰያት፡ እምኔሁ፡ አንጻረ፡ ምድረ፡ ኢትዮጵያ፡ ትሰመይ፡ ደሰያተ፡ ንቡራተ። ወደሴት፡ ካልእት፡ ትሰመይ፡ አድራ። ወዛቲ፡ ደሴት፡ አንጻረ፡ አንድሎስ፡ ኀበ፡ ፈለግ፡ እስመ፡ ፈለግ፡ ዘይወፅእ፡ እምባሕር፡ እስመ፡ ግድሙ፡ ፬ምዕራፍ። ወውእቱ፡ ማእከለ፡ አንድሎስ፡ ወጠንጋ፡ ወይሰመይ፡ ሴጣ፡ ይወፅእ፡ እምባሕረ፡ ሮም። ወውስቴቱ፡ ካዕበ፡ እመንገለ፡ ጸጋም፡ ፲ወ፪ደሰያት፡ እለ፡ ይሰመዩ፡ ደሰያተ፡ በርጦንያ። ወዓዲ፡ ይርሕቅ፡ እምነ፡ ዘየኀድሩ፡ ሰብእ፡ ውስቴቱ፡ ወኢየአምር፡ መኑሂ፡ እፎ፡ ውእቱ። ወባሕረ፡ ሮምሰ፡ ወግብጽ፡ ወይከውን፡ ኀበ፡ ፈለግ፡ ዘይወፅእ፡ እምባሕር፡ ሐመልሚል፡ ኀበ፡ ምሥራቅ፡ እስከ፡ ጢሮስ፡ ወእስከ፡ ሲዶና። ኑኁ፡ ፶፻ምዕራፍ፡ ወግድሙ፡ ኀበ፡ መካን፡ ፰፻ምዕራፍ። ወውስቴቱ፡ ፩ፈለግ፡ ይወፅእ፡ እምኀበ፡ መንገለ፡ ጸጋም፡ ቅሩብ፡ እምሮምያ። ኑኁ፡ ፭፻ምዕራፍ፡ ወይሰመይ፡ ህንድሪስ። ወፈለግ፡ ካልእ፡ ይወፅእ፡ አንጻረ፡ ምድረ፡ በርበራዊት። ኑኁ፡ ፪፻ምዕራፍ። ወውስቴቱ፡ ፻፷ወ፪ደሰያት፡ ዘየኀድሩ፡ ውስቴቶሙ፡ ሰብእ፡ ወእምኔሆሙ፡ ደሰያት፡ ዐበይት፡ ፲ወ፭ደሴት። ወአፍላጋት፡ የዐውድዎ።

div.label: Story of the Ethiopian wife of Moses
div.note: The following section on the alleged Ethiopian wife of Moses is based on the edition by 276-278, which is based on the attestations in London, British Library, BL Oriental 814, fols 24v-25r, ʾAddis ʾAbabā, Manbara Lǝʿul Qəddus Mārqos, EMML 21, fols 20r-21v and Collegeville, Hill Museum and Manuscript Library, MS EMML no. 192, fol. 14r.
div.ab: ወበውእቱ፡ መዋዕል፡ ተፃብኡ፡ ሰብአ፡ ኵሳ፡ ዘውእቶሙ፡ ሰብአ፡ ኢትዮጵያ፡ ምስለ፡ ሰብአ፡ ግብጽ፡ ወአመዝበሩ፡ ብሔሮሙ። ወሜጥዎ፡ ለማየ፡ ተከዜ፡ ኀበ፡ ካልእ፡ ፍኖት፡ ከመ፡ ኢየሩጽ፡ ለሀገሮሙ፡ እስመ፡ ምጽአተ፡ ማዮሙ፡ እምኢትዮጵያ። ወእምድኅረዝ፡ አምከርዎ፡ ሰብእ፡ ለንጉሠ፡ ግብጽ፡ ከመ፡ ይፈንዎ፡ ለሙሴ፡ ያፅብዖሙ፡ ለሰብአ፡ ኢትዮጵያ፡ ወይቤሎሙ፡ ኦሆ። ወይቤልዎ፡ ኦሙሴ፡ እስመ፡ አእመርከ፡ ኵሎ፡ ዘመጽአ፡ ላዕሌነ፡ እምኢትዮጵያውያን፡ ወከመዝ፡ በርዋ፡ ለሀገርነ፡ ወፄወዉ፡ ሰብእ፡ ወመተሩ፡ ማየ፡ ተከዜ፡ እምኔሃ፡ ወሜጥዎ። ያደልወከ፡ ትርጻእ፡ መንግሥተ፡ በእንተ፡ ዘጸገወተከ፡ አምሠናያት፡ አንተ፡ ተአምሮሙ፡ ወኢትከሐዶሙ። ናሁ፡ ፈቀደ፡ ንጉሥ፡ ወኵሉ፡ መኳንንቲሁ፡ ከመ፡ ትሑር፡ ኀበ፡ ኢትዮጵያ፡ ወትፅባዕ፡ ሰብእ። ንሣእ፡ ዘኃረይከ፡ እምሠራዊት፡ ወኩን፡ ሊቀ፡ ላዕሌሆሙ፡ ወኀረየ፡ እምደቂቀ፡ እሥራኤል፡ ፼ ብአሴ፡ መስተፅዕናነ፡ አፍራስ። ወምግብጻውያን፡ ፼መስተፅዕናነ፡ አፍራስ፡ ወበጽሐ፡ ሙሴ፡ ውስተ፡ ገዳም፡ ወሰምዐ፡ ከመ፡ ሀለዉ፡ አክይስት፡ ወአፍዖት፡ ብዙኅ፡ በፍኖት፡ ማእከለ፡ ግብጽ፡ ወኢትዮጵያ። ወነሥአ፡ ሙሴ፡ እምአዕዋፍ፡ ዘይበልዑ፡ አክይስተ፡ ብዙኃ፡ ወእምኔሆሙ፡ ጊጳ፡ ወአልዮጦን፡ ወገላውቃ። ወሶበ፡ በጽሐ፡ ኀበ፡ ውእቱ፡ ምድር፡ አዘዘ፡ ከመ፡ ኢይብልዕዎሙ፡ ለእልክቱ፡ አዕዋፍ፡ ዘእንበለ፡ ጊዜ፡ ወጽባሕ፡ እመዓልት። ወኮነ፡ ሶበ፡ ይወርዱ፡ ሠራዊት፡ ያርሳዉ፡ ሙዳያተ፡ ወደዘርዉ፡ አዕዋፍ፡ ውስተ፡ ማኅደሪሆሙ፡ ለሠራዊት፡ ወኢይብልዑ፡ ምንተኒ። ወኮኑ፡ ይነቆዉ፡ ኵላ፡ ሌሊተ፡ በእንተ፡ ብዝኃ፡ ረኃቦሙ፡ ወይሰምዑ፡ አክይስት፡ ቃላቲሆሙ፡ ወይትኃብኡ፡ ውስተ፡ ምድር፡ በእንተ፡ ብዝኃ፡ ፍርሃቶሙ፡ እምኔሆሙ፡ ወገብረ፡ ከመዝ፡ እስከ፡ በጽሐ፡ ኢትዮጵያ። ወሶበ፡ ርእዩ፡ ሰብአ፡ ኵሳ፡ ኢትዮጵያ፡ ብዝኃ፡ ሠራዊት፡ ዐፀቦሙ፡ ፈድፋደ፡ ወፈርሁ፡ ዓቢየ፡ ፍርሃተ፡ ወተፃብኡ፡ ዐቢየ፡ ፀብአ፡ ወሞአዎሙ፤ ወሶበ፡ ጠየቀት፡ ወለተ፡ ንጉሠ፡ ኢትዮጵያ፡ ከመ፡ ሙሴ፡ ሞኦሙ፡ ወፈቀደ፡ ይቅትል፡ ኵሎ፡ ዘውስቴታ፡ ፈነወት፡ ኀቤሁ፡ መልአክታ፡ ከመ፡ ያውስባ፡ ወተምርሖ፡ ፍኖተ፡ እንተ፡ ባቲ፡ የመውኦሙ። ወተሠጥዋ፡ በዝንቱ፡ ወነገረቶ፡ መካናተ፡ ለበዊአ፡ ሀገር፡ ወተሠልጠ፡ ላዕለ፡ መንግሥት። ወአውሰበ፡ ሙሴ፡ ወለተ፡ ንጉሠ፡ ኢትዮጵያ፡ ወይእቲ፡ ኢትዮጵያዊት፡ በከመ፡ ይቤ፡ መጽሐፈ፡ ኦሪት፡ አስመ፡ ማርያም፡ ወአሮን፡ ሐመይዎ፡ ለሙሴ፡ በእንተ፡ ዘአውሰበ፡ በብእሲተ፡ ኢትዮጵያዊት፡ ዘኢኮነት፡ ቀይሕተ። ወነበረ፡ ሙሴ፡ ወሠራዊት፡ እለ፡ ምስሌሁ፡ ውስተ፡ ምድረ፡ ኢትዮጵያ፡ እስከ፡ ጊዜ፡ የዓርግ፡ ወደመልአ፡ ተከዜ፡ ወጠየቀ፡ ግብሮ። ወነደቀ፡ ናሕሰ፡ ዓቢየ፡ በአዕባን፡ ወበግንፉል፡ ዘውእቱ፡ ግብሰሶ፡ ከመ፡ ይዕቀብ፡ ማየ፡ ሶበ፡ ይትዌሰክ፡ እስከ፡ ይረዊ፡ ምድረ፡ ኢትዮጵያ፡ ወትነሥኡ፡ ምድረ፡ ዘፈቀደት፡ እምኔሁ። ወዓዲ፡ ይረድ፡ ማይ፡ ኀበ፡ ምድረ፡ ግብጽ፡ ወሤመ፡ ሙሴ፡ እኀወ፡ ብእሲቱ፡ ላዕለ፡ መንግሥተ፡ ኢትዮጵያ፡ ወአምሐሎ፡ ኢይምትር፡ ማየ፡ እምነ፡ ምድረ፡ ግብጽ፡ ኀበ፡ ካልእ፡ ፍኖት።

div.label: 92nd Generation - Alexander the Great
div.note: The following section on life and deeds of is based on the edition of 207-225, which is based on the attestation in London, British Library, BL Oriental 814, folio 69vc-74vb.
div.ab:
፺፪እምአዳም። እስክንድር፡ ወልደ፡ ፊልጶስ፡ ዮናናዊ፡ መቄዶናዊ፡ ወይሰመይ፡ ዘቦ፡ ፪ አቅርንት፡ ወተገዓዙ፡ ሰብእ፡ በእንተ፡ መንግሥቱ፡ ወበእንተ፡ አቅርንቲሁ፡ ፪ ቦእምኔሆሙ፡ ዘይቤ፡ ከመ፡ ቦቱ፡ መካነ፡ ፪ አቅርንት፡ ውስተ፡ ርእሱ፡ ክሡተ፡ ወኮነ፡ ይከብቶ፡ እምሰብእ። ወቦ፡ ዘይቤ፡ ከመ፡ ውእቱ፡ ተሰምየ፡ ዘ፪ አቅርንት፡ እስመ፡ ነግሠ፡ በ፪ አቅርንተ፡ ፀሐይ፡ እምሥራቅ፡ እስከ፡ ምዕራብ። ወተጋዓዙ፡ ጸሐፍተ፡ ሐሳብ፡ በእንቲአሁ፡ ወተዋሥኡ፡ ፈድፋደ። ይቤ፡ ጸሐፈፊ፡ ዝንቱ፡ ታሪክ፡ እስመ፡ አነ፡ አንበብኩ፡ ዜናሁ፡ እምብዙኀ፡ መጻሐፍት፡ ወብዙኀ፡ ቃላት፡ ወናሁ፡ ኃረይኩ፡ እምኔሃ፡ ዘይበቊዕ፡ እምዜናሁ፡ ከመ፡ ውእቱ፡ ነግሠ፡ እምድኀረ፡ እቡሁ፡ ላዕለ፡ መንግሥተ፡ መቄዶንያ፡ እንዘ፡ መዋዕሊሁ፡ ፲ወ፯ዓመት። ወሰምዐ፡ ዳርዮስ፡ ዘይልህቅ፡ እምንጉሥ፡ ፋርስ፡ ወባቢሎን፡ ወነነዌ፡ ወካልአን፡ እምበሐውርት፡ ከመ፡ እስክንድር፡ ነግሠ፡ ላዕለ፡ ሮም፡ ወተሀበለ፡ ላዕሌሁ፡ በእንተ፡ ንዕስ

div.label: History of Abu Tahir al-Mansur Billah
History of al-Aziz Imad ad-Din Uthman

div.note: This division into textparts and labels follows the devision in .

div.label: Attribution to the author and outline of the content by the translator.
Introduction
div.note: General introduction by the author containing a note on the final redaction of the work as well as chronographic and cosmographic considerations as witnessed in the Arabic edition in 176-191.

div.label: Authors Preface
div.note: Note by the author, in which he claims that his work was already circulating in Egypt when he decided to add a story from another source about the Persian Empire (e.g. 'Ruzbihans history').

div.label: Discourse on the temporality of the world
Discourse on the nature of time
Discourse about the quantity of time and how much of it has elapsed
Discourse on the commencement of the Creation
Geographical Treatise
div.note: Based on the translation of 104-207.

div.label: Descendants of Shem
div.ab: The number of people gathered for the construction of the tower was 72 captains. Among them were of Shem's descendants, 25 men. They lived from the Euphrates to Syria and to the eastern edge. They included the Syrians, the areas of Rabiʿā (= Diyar Rabi'a), the island of Wäḥarāmqā (= Ǧarāmiqa), the Chaldeans - that is the people of Babylon - as well as Persia, Khorasan, Fergana, Sind, India, Temān (= Yemen), Ṭayf, Tamāmā (= al-Yamāma) and two seas and the descendants of the Arabs. Those who know how to write letters are 8: Hebrew, Syrian, Persian, Indian, Chaldean, Chinese, ḥāmāzi (= Himyaric) and Arabic. They have the Euphrates and the river Balch as rivers.

div.label: Descendants of Ham
div.ab: Of the descendants of Ham there are 32 men. They inhabited the land of Syria and the land of Canaan as far as the land of Egypt as well as the western fringes. From them (came) the Canaanites, the Philistines, the Egyptians, the Māris (= Meroites), the descendants of the Ethiopians and the land of the Blacks as well as the Zendj, the people of the West and the Berbers. They have 26 islands with names such as Sardinia, Malta, Crete and others around them. The letters they wrote were 7 (sic): Coptic, Nubian, Ethiopian, Frankish, qolāqi (= Phoenician?) and qiləqi (= Cilician?). They have the Nile as a (major) river and the Jordan as a river.

div.label: Descendants of Japhet
div.ab: There were 15 men among the descendants of Japhet. They lived from the Tigris to the far north of the world. Among them are the Turks, the Nəḥyān (= the Pechenegs), the Ṭaʿārʿir (= the Ṭoġuzġuz), the Natəb (= Tibetans), Gog and Magog, the Ḥarzä Wālän (= the Khazars, the Alans), ʾAygār (= Abkhazia), Ṣabāyər (= Siberian), Greater Armenia and Lesser Armenia, Antioch, Kaldəyā (= Chaldia), Cappadocia, Karastā (= Jerash?), Greece, Rome, Britain, Russia, Dailam (= Dalmatia), Slavonia, Franconia, Andalusia and what that follows. They have twelve islands, including: Rhodes, Sicily, Cyprus and Athens (sic!). They have 7 (sic!) alphabets that they know how to write: Greek, Roman, Armenian, Andalusian, Frankish and ḥərzāwi (= Khazar). In terms of rivers, they have the Tigris and the Siṭ (= Ister/Danube). The writer of this book said: 'Thus have I remembered the parts of the whole earth, as the descendants of Noah divided it.

div.label: Margins of inhabited earth
div.ab: Once more we must explain the boundaries of the climes and their outlines, and the wonders and peculiarities within them. We shall report what we have discovered of the works of each of the peoples who dwell in them - and of the events to which they have been subjected. For the climes, we will tell you about the lions, cattle, birds and animals that can be found in each clime. The division of the countries is as explained by the wise Ptolemy: They are divided into five parts. Four of them are desolate and no man and no one lives in them. The first part is the eastern fringe - in it is a fire of constant heat. No animals live (in it). The second part is the northern (sic!), which lies to the right of (sic!) the first part. Its heat increases a lot because it is close to it. Nobody can live in it. The third part is to the west. It contains seas that cannot be navigable and its islands are desolate. The fourth part is the northern one, which is next to the seventh clime. In it there is a lot of cold and harsh dryness. There is always ice and snow. Neither animals nor livestock live in it. The fifth part is the one in the centre of the earth where people live. This is divided into seven parts. These are the well-known and famous 7 climes, which are now listed:

div.label: Earth and Sun
div.ab: We must first make it clear that the Earth is round, like a bowl. The part in the centre - the one in which the whole creation dwells - is very much elevated above the four parts that are desolate. These four parts are much lower than the fifth. That is why the sun is obscured by this clime when it descends into the area the low-lying countries and darkness spreads. This time is called night. The day is long when the sun rises in the northern orbit - of the 12 constellations - at the head of the star Säräṭan. Its duration is the end of the night (?) when the sun sets in the southern orbits, which we mentioned are excessively cold.

div.label: First clime
div.ab: Ptolemy declared that the first of the the 7 climes has its beginning near the place of the burnt land. This clime is the one towards India and distant China. Its longest day stretches over 13 hours.

div.label: Second clime
div.ab: The second clime is the country from Cush to Ethiopia. Its longest day stretches over 13 and a half hours.

div.label: Third clime
div.ab: The third clime is the clime of Alexandria and Egypt. Its longest day stretches over 14 hours.

div.label: Fourth clime
div.ab: The fourth clime, on the other hand, is called “Rhodes” in the Roman language - an island that lies in the sea. In this clime, the land of Syria, the land of the ʽislandʼ (= al-Ǧazīra) - in which Babylon is located - and other countries are included. Its longest day stretches over 14 and a half hours.

div.label: Fifth clime
div.ab: The fifth clime is called in Roman ʽPontosʼ. It contains Constantinople, Amoria and Rome. Its longest day stretches over 15 hours.

div.label: Sixth clime
div.ab: The sixth clime is the land of Bargān (= Burǧān) and the surrounding area. Its longest day is 15 and a half hours.

div.label: Seventh clime
div.ab: The seventh clime is called in Roman ʽYāros and the surrounding areaʼ. Its longest day extends over 16 hours.

div.label: Width of the inhabited earth
div.ab: We will now explain the extent of each clime - each of the seven climes in which people live. Their width - that is, the width of the seven climes in which people live, which are in the centre of the earth, the beginning of which is India and distant China towards the fiery land, to the end of the seventh clime - that is, from the southern edge to the north, the width of everything, as divided by the wise Ptolemy, is 63 degrees. The width of each individual clime is 9 degrees. One degree is 3 days of travel - that makes 27 days of travel. Every 1 degree is 100 miles.

div.label: Length of the inhabited earth
div.ab: The beginning of this clime is in the east (and it reaches) to its end in the west. Its length is 180 degrees. One half of the sphere is above and one half is below. Its entire lenght from the sea of Okeanos to its end in the east is 160 days of travel. 160 - (this corresponds to) the number of 5700 parasangs according to the reckoning of the Persians and the peoples of the East. Furthermore, one parasang corresponds to 4 miles. We believe that the width of this first clime, which began at the boundary of the burning land, extends to the boundary of Sarandib (= Sri Lanka). The dimension of its width from south to north is 285 parasangs.

div.label: The seven climes and their inhabitants
Inhabitants of the first clime
div.ab: Those who dwell in this clime - distant China and India, on a strip from the end of the earth in the east to its edge in the west - are always naked people - ugly is their face and evil is their nature. They are descendants of Ham. They have knowledge of sorcery and witchcraft. Their days (= age) are long. In this clime, there are large, very terrible beasts and hoofed animals as well as large birds - including birds that are (similar to) the hoofed animals; the bird that is like the ostrich; the ʾAgriṗā; the ʾAlyāṭon; and the bird called the ‘elephant bird’. In this clime there are large elephants, terrible reptiles and a large snake. Among the people there are those who know woods and stones, which they make themselves and which are a salvation. In it is a cure from these terrible dragons and (other) animals. They place it on those who have been attacked by these evil dragons and they then survive.

div.label: Inhabitants of the second clime
div.ab: The second clime, which is Ethiopia: Its length extends from the border of Sarandib (Sri Lanka) to the the end of the country of Ethiopia in the west, as well as to the mountains where hyacinths, precious stones and grains of gold are found. Those who live in them are from nearby China, Sind and India. In this clime, there are also large, terrible hoofed animals and (other) animals. But they are smaller than those in the first clime. In this clime, there are woods and stones in which, because of their nature, are a remedy for those who have been bitten by the animals of the creation from this (clime). There are those who live in this clime who have knowledge of witches, magic formulae, medicines and healing with wood and stones. Their days (= age) are shorter compared to the days of those living in the first clime. Its length and its width are like the first (clime).

div.label: Inhabitants of the third clime
div.ab: The third clime is the clime of Alexandria. This clime has its beginning at the tip of the land of Egypt in the west - its east is in the direction of the land of Sandos (= Sind?). Its length extends from the west to the border of outer Syria and Persia minor as well as to the border of Alexandria and the areas of Barka and Africa minor. Those who live in this clime are explorers because of their lasting achievements. Its length and its width are like the first (clime).

div.label: Inhabitants of the fourth clime
div.note: Including a list of the ten sciences.

div.label: Inhabitants of the fifth clime
div.ab: The fifth clime is known as Həlus and Bənṭus (= Hellespont). It is the one in which Constantinople, Amoria, Rome, Andalusia and the countries of Africa are (located). Those who live there are red people who are very lustful, strong, very irritable and hot-tempered - just like as their father Esau was. They have little wisdom - the knowledge is from the fourth clime. They are a wild people with no discipline, but they rush to receive instruction so that they may learn quickly. But when they dwell in the fourth clime, they are kind and have a purer heart than those who live in this clime. Its length and its width are like the first (clime).

div.label: Inhabitants of the sixth clime
div.note: Including a description of the Amazons.
div.ab: The sixth clime, known as ‘Soryo Ṭomis’ (= ‘dia pontu mesu’), belongs to the islands of the sea. Those who live in this clime are the peoples of the Bargān, the Slavs and the Bāʿdān (= Amazons). There are women who live alone in this clime with no men living with them. They always cut off their right breasts and put fire in them, so that they do not become large and shed blood, so that they are ready to fight and kill, because the Sāmərs (= Samirus) fight against them and kill their male children whom they have given birth to. That is why they do not raise their male children, but they only raise their female children. Every year they go to the areas of the men, get married and get pregnant. When they are pregnant, they return back to their homes. This is a well-known fact and nobody doubts it. The people of this clime who impregnate the women are skilled in killing, men who fight and spill blood. They have no compassion. That is why they capture the Slavs and turn them into castrati. They are people who have no knowledge, no books, no laws, no education at all. Its length and its width are like the first (clime).

div.label: Inhabitants of the seventh clime
div.ab: The seventh clime is the one known as Yārəs Bārəs (= Borysthenes). This is the clime where the people live who are called in Roman ʽBamidosʼ (= Numidians) - which means ‘the sleepy ones’. They are weak people who move little due to their great, excessive cold, as they are close to the north and the desert areas where no humans live. The stars, which are called ‘Daughters of the Stretcher’ (= Plough / Big Dipper), are close to them, always circling above them. Their cattle and the animals of their clime are very small. Their sheep have no horns because of the bitter cold. Snakes or anything that moves by crawling cannot be found in their clime. As they cannot build houses to live in, they rather make houses out of wood, put them on a wagon and live in them. Their cattle pull it. They wander around day and night, as their cattle pull this vehicle to a to (a place) where they can find food and pastures for their cattle. In their bad behaviour and life they are pathetic at all times. It is said about them that when they suffer from a serious illness, they place their sick on a wagon. They take off their their men's clothes and put them in women's clothes - then they are healed. Its length and its width are like the first (clime).

div.label: Inhabitants of the regions above the seventh clime
div.note: Including a description of the polar night and polar day.
div.ab: He said: ‘What goes beyond the end of the 63 degrees of width - that is what was called “beyond the seventh clime”. The day does not depart - when it extends northwards, it is beyond the land where people live - for 21 hours and 22 minutes from one hour (sic!) until it extends over 24 (hours). Thus the daylight does not give way until the land of darkness. The night is six months and the day is six months here. There are too many wonders that exist on earth in a particular clime, and talismans that are sought and produced, and there is no number to count them. But we only want to mention the little that is mentioned in the history book, to which we have referred. We have not added anyhing to what is written, so as not to prolong the story.

div.label: The Indian sea
div.ab: They also measured and estimated the sea of India. They said that its longitude stretches from west to east - that is from the coast of India to the coast of Ethiopia - this longitude is 8000 miles and its latitudinal extent is 2700 miles - until it approaches the island of the equinox. The other coastline is 2900 (miles). There is a small gulf in the country of Ethiopia that extends towards Barbār. It is called 'Barbarian Gulf'. Its length is 500 miles and the width at its end is 100 miles. It has by another gulf in the direction of Eilat. Its length is 1400 miles and its width 700 miles. Its termination - that is its end - which close to the so-called Erythraean Sea, is 200 miles long. It has another gulf that extends towards Persia, which is called the ‘Persian Gulf’. Its length is 1400 miles, its width width 500 miles and its end 150 miles. Between these two seas, there is the land of Qedār, the son of Ishmael, and the land of Yemen. Between the Gulf of Eilat and the Persian Gulf is 1500 miles. Another gulf stretches from it to the coast of the country of India. It is called the ‘Green Gulf’. Opposite to the land of India - from the land of India in the east - (there is an island) called ‘Ṭirabāy’ (= Sri Lanka). 3000 miles surround it. There are large mountains and many rivers on it. From it comes the red emerald and (the gemstone of) the colour of the sky. This island is surrounded by 90 islands on which people live and towns are numerous.

div.label: The Green sea
div.ab: Nothing is known of the Green Sea except what extends to the west and north - from the border of the country of Ethiopia to Barṭonyā (= Britain). It is a sea on which no ships sail. Seven (sic!) of its islands are opposite the country of Ethiopia. They are called the 'inhabited (!) islands' (= Canaries). Another island is called ʾAdrā (= Gadera / Cadiz). This island is opposite to Andalusia, next to a gulf, namely the gulf that flows out of the sea, whose width is four miles, which is between Andalusia and Tangier and which is called Seṭā (= Ceuta) and which flows out of the Sea from Rome. In it (= in the Green Sea) to the north (there are also) twelve islands, which are called the Islands of Britain. And then one moves away from (the place) where people live and nobody knows what it is like. The Sea of Rome and Egypt is (attached) to the sea that comes out of the Green Sea - in the east as far as Tyre and Sidon. Its length is 5000 miles and its width is 800 miles at one point. There is a gulf in it that reaches as far north as close to Rome. Its length is 500 miles and it is is called Hǝndǝris (= the Adriatic Sea). Another gulf emerges opposite the Barbarian Land. Its length is 200 miles. There are 162 islands in it on which people live on, including 15 large islands. Currents flow through it.

div.label: Story of the Ethiopian wife of Moses
div.note: The following section on the alleged Ethiopian wife of Moses is based on the translation by 276-278.
div.ab: At that time, the people of Cush, who are the people of Ethiopia, waged war against the people of Egypt. They destroyed their land and diverted the water of the Takkaze (= Nile) to another route so that it would no longer flow into their land because their water came from Ethiopia. Then the people persuaded the king of Egypt to send Moses to make war on the people of Ethiopia. He said to them, 'All right'. And they said: 'O Moses, do you know what happened to us because of the Ethiopians? They destroyed our land, they captured the people, then they cut off the water of the Takkaze (= the Nile) and diverted it. It is right that you should help the kingdom because of the grace it has shown you out of kindness. He (= Moses) was shown to them as a sign and he did not betray them. Now the king wants you and all his officers to go to Ethiopia and wage war against the people (of Ethiopia). Take the army you have chosen and be their leader'. And he chose 10,000 horsemen from among the children of Israel and 10,000 horsemen from among the Egyptian people. When Moses came to the desert, he heard that there were snakes and vipers on the road between Egypt and Ethiopia. Moses took from among the birds those that eat many snakes, and among them the vulture, the ʾalyoton and the owl. When he came to this land, he commanded them not to feed any of these birds except at dawn. And it happened that when the soldiers came down, they opened the cages and distributed the birds around the army camp, and they ate nothing. They cried all night, because they were very hungry. The snakes heard their cries and hid in the ground because they were so frightened. And he (Moses) did this until he reached Ethiopia. When the people of Cush, (people of) Ethiopia, saw many soldiers, they were greatly troubled and they were afraid with great fear. They (the Egyptians) fought a great battle and defeated them. When the daughter of the king of Ethiopia heard that Moses had defeated them and he wanted to kill everyone who was there, she sent a message to him so that he would take her as his wife and she would guide him on the path by which he would be victorious. And he received it like this. She showed him the places to enter the city and he took possession of the kingdom. Moses married the daughter of the king of Ethiopia. This is the Ethiopian woman, who is mentioned in the Old Testament: Maryam and Aron accused Moses of marrying an Ethiopian woman who was not red. Moses remained with the soldiers who spread out with him in the land of Ethiopia until the day of the flood and the deluge of the Takkaze (= Nile) and observed his work. And he built a great wall of stones and masonry bricks so that it would protect the water when it increased, until the land of Ethiopia was watered. And it occupied the land that it needed after that. Again the water flowed to the land of Egypt. Moses appointed the brother of his wife as head of the kingdom of Ethiopia and made him swear not to divert the water of Egypt to another path.
